questions: Where do you find green glands?
answers: In prawns (crustaceans).

questions: Name two parts of a nephron.
answers: (a) Glomerulus (b) Renal tubule.

questions: From where the pelvis receives urine?
answers: The pelvis receives urine from collecting tubules via calyces.

questions: Which is the most toxic product formed in animals?
answers: Ammonia (NH2) is the most toxic product formed in animals.

questions: Give the total amount of water excreted daily through human body.
answers: The total amount of water excreted daily through human body is 2.60 litres.

questions: Name the organs concerned with excretion in man.
answers: Kidneys are the major excretory organs. Other accessory excretory structures are liver, lungs, skin and intestine.

questions: Why ammonia is converted to uric acid crystals directly in uricotelic organisms?
answers: Animals which live in dry conditions have to conserve water in their bodies. Therefore, they synthesize crystals of uric acid from their ammonia.

questions: Where are the kidneys located in human beings?
answers: The kidneys are located between the levels of the last thoracic and third lumbar vertebrae close to the dorsal inner wall of the abdominal cavity.

questions: What are the ducts of Bellini?
answers: These are the collecting ducts which unite together in the medulla to form the longer duct, the duct of Bellini.

questions: Name two high threshold substances.
answers: Glucose and amino acids are two threshold substances.

questions: What is a Malpighian corpuscle?
answers: Bowman's capsule and glomerulus are collectively known as Malpighian corpuscles.

questions: What are osmoconformers?
answers: Osmoconformers are those animals which show changes in the body fluid concentration according to the concentration of surrounding medium.

questions: What are guanotelic animals?
answers: The three process of urine formation are: (a) Ultrafiltration, (b) Selective reabsorption (c) Tubular secretion.

questions: Why is sweat considered as a excretory waste?
answers: Sweat is considered as a excretory waste because it contains nitrogenous wastes, dissolved salts and excess of water.

questions: Expand the following terms: (i) ANF (ii) JGA
answers: (i) ANF: Atrial Natriuretic Factor (ii) JGA: Juxta Glomerular Apparatus.

questions: What are renal calculi?
answers: Stone or insoluble mass of crystallised salts such as oxalates are called as renal calculi.

questions: What happens in glomerulonephritis?
answers: Inflammation of glomeruli of the kidneys.

questions: What is gout?
answers: High level of uric acid accumulation in the body which tends to solidify into crystals and are deposited in the joints and kidneys.

questions: What is osmoregulation?
answers: Removal of excess water from the body to keep water content constant is called osmoregulation.

questions: How thyroxine deficiency affects the urine?
answers: Thyroxine deficiency decreases the urine output.

questions: Define osmolarity.
answers: Osmolarity is the total solute concentration of two solutions.

questions: Name the enzyme produced by kidney to convert angiotensinogen to angiotensin.
answers: Renin converts angiotensinogen to angiotensin.

questions: What is urinolysis?
answers: An analysis of urine is called urinolysis which provides information about the physical, chemical and microscopic properties of urine.

questions: What is the function of juxta-medullary nephrons?
answers: Juxta-medullary nephrons control plasma volume when water supply is short.

questions: What is the role of anti-diuretic hormone in excretion?
answers: Anti-diuretic hormone increases the reabsorption of water in the distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct.

questions: How is uremia caused? Define the term uremia.
answers: Uremia is caused by high concentration of urea in the blood.

questions: Expand RAAS.
answers: RAAS is Renin Angiotensinogen Aldosterone system.

questions: If urine contains blood what does this indicates?
answers: If urine contains blood, this indicates there has been some injury or damage to the filters of the kidneys.

questions: What is diuretic? Give Examples.
answers: A substance which increase the volume of urine excreted is called diuretic. e.g., tea, coffee etc.
